questions.text: Listen! Someone is knocking on the door.
questions.explanation: The correct preposition to use with 'knock' is 'at'.

questions.text: There are more than six hundred people in our village.
questions.explanation: 'Over' is synonymous with 'more than'.

questions.text: One fourth of the teachers are women.
questions.explanation: 'One fourth' is equivalent to 'a quarter'.

questions.text: His parents often go to work by car.
questions.explanation: 'Parents' refers to both 'father and mother'.

questions.text: They enjoyed themselves yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Enjoyed themselves' means 'had a good time'.

questions.text: I have two <blank> in my pencil-box.
questions.explanation: The plural form of 'knife' is 'knives'.

questions.text: The desks are made <blank> wood.
questions.explanation: When the material remains visible, we use 'of'.

questions.text: - Whose book is this? Is this yours? -- No, it's <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Hers' is the possessive pronoun.

questions.text: Which is <blank>, English or Chinese?
questions.explanation: When comparing two items, use the comparative form ('more interesting').

questions.text: -Must they clean the classroom now? -- No, they <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Needn't' expresses lack of necessity.

questions.text: We'll go to the zoo if it <blank> fine this afternoon.
questions.explanation: Use the present simple tense after 'if' to talk about the future.

questions.text: Mrs White <blank> in this school since she came here.
questions.explanation: Use the present perfect tense to indicate an action that started in the past and continues to the present.

questions.text: The teacher told us not <blank> in the sun.
questions.explanation: 'Not to read' is the negative form of the infinitive.

questions.text: The PLA <blank> in 1927.
questions.explanation: 'Founded' means 'established'. 'Was founded' is the passive voice.

questions.text: Your father has been to Guangzhou twice, <blank>?
questions.explanation: Use 'hasn't he' as the tag question for 'has been'.

questions.text: <blank> any noise in class.
questions.explanation: 'Don't make' is the correct imperative form.

questions.text: Can you tell me <blank>?
questions.explanation: Use subject + verb order in reported questions.

questions.text: Do you enjoy <blank> in China?
questions.explanation: Enjoy + doing sth. is a fixed expression.

questions.text: <blank> hard they are working!
questions.explanation: How + adj/adv + subject + verb is used to express exclamation

questions.text: Do you have <blank> to say?
questions.explanation: Adjectives usually come after 'anything' and 'something'

questions.text: <blank> are going to England for a holiday.
questions.explanation: When referring to a family, 'The + last name' is used. To make it plural, add an 's'.

questions.text: These <blank> were sent to the villages to help the farmers.
questions.explanation: The subject is plural, so both 'woman' and 'doctor' should be in their plural forms. The plural form of woman is women.

questions.text: Please remember to give the horse some tree <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Leaves' is the plural form of 'leaf'. Horses usually eat more than one leaf.

questions.text: Will you please show me the way to the <blank> shop?
questions.explanation: A shop selling shoes will generally sell more than one pair of shoes, hence, 'shoes' should be plural.

questions.text: Help yourselves to some <blank>, dear children!
questions.explanation: 'Fish' is an uncountable noun. It can be used as plural without adding 's'.

questions.text: What <blank> lovely weather it is!
questions.explanation: The sentence follows the structure 'What + a/an + adjective + noun'.

questions.text: Do you believe that there are two <blank> in my class?
questions.explanation: When a name ends with a 'y', change the 'y' to 'i' and add 'es' to make it plural.

questions.text: ―Help yourself to <blank>. ―Thanks. Mmmmm…it tastes good.
questions.explanation: 'Chicken' as a food is an uncountable noun. 'Some' is used to offer uncountable nouns.

questions.text: I met two <blank> in the street yesterday morning.
questions.explanation: To refer to people from a country, use the plural form of the nationality.

questions.text:
--Can I help you, sir?
--I'd like to have 10 <blank>. I want the students to draw pictures on them.
questions.explanation: 'Paper' is an uncountable noun and can be used directly without 'pieces of'.

questions.text: September 10th is <blank> Day.
questions.explanation: Possessive case is needed here. Teacher's day is the day of teacher.

questions.text:
―Did you and your friends ride your bike to the beach yesterday afternoon?
―Yeah. <blank> we had!
questions.explanation: 'Fun' is an uncountable noun, so 'a' is not needed. 'What fun' is the correct exclamation.
questions.test_point: Nouns; Countable & Uncountable Nouns; Exclamatory Sentences

questions.text: They got much <blank> from those new books.
questions.explanation: 'Information' is an uncountable noun. 'Much' is used for uncountable nouns.

questions.text: What big <blank> the tiger has!
questions.explanation: Tigers have more than one tooth, 'teeth' is the plural form of 'tooth'.

questions.text: <blank> are <blank> for cutting things.
questions.explanation: 'Knives' is the plural form of 'knife', since we are describing the function of knives in general, the plural form is more appropriate.
questions.test_point: Nouns; Plural Forms; General Statements; Passive Voice

questions.text: Tables are made of <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Wood' as a material is an uncountable noun.

questions.text: He gave us <blank> on how to keep fit.
questions.explanation: 'Advice' is an uncountable noun, so it does not have a plural form.

questions.text: -Can we have some <blank>? -Yes, please.
questions.explanation: Since the question is 'some', the answer should be the plural form of a noun.

questions.text: He is hungry. Give him <blank> to eat.
questions.explanation: 'Bread' is an uncountable noun, it should be used with measure words like 'piece'.

questions.text: Some <blank> came to our school for a visit that day.
questions.explanation: To refer to people from a country, use the plural form of the nationality.

questions.text: -How many <blank> have you got on your farm? -I've got five.
questions.explanation: 'Sheep' is a noun that has the same form in both singular and plural.

questions.text: Mike hurt one of his <blank> in the accident yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Feet' is the plural form of 'foot'. We have two feet.

questions.text:
-- It's dangerous here. We'd better go out quickly.
- - But I think we should let <blank> go out first.
questions.explanation: Both 'woman' and 'child' should be in their plural forms.

questions.text: In a few <blank> time, those mountains will be covered with trees.
questions.explanation: Here 'few' means 'a short time'.

questions.text: In the picture there are many <blank> and two <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Sheep' is the same in singular and plural forms.

questions.text: This table is made of <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Glass' as a material is uncountable, so use 'glass' directly.

questions.text: Children should make <blank> for old people in a bus.
questions.explanation: 'Room' here means space, and it is an uncountable noun.

questions.text: I wonder why <blank> are so interested in action films.
questions.explanation: 'People' is plural. 'The people' means a specific group of people.

questions.text: If these pants are too big, buy a smaller <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Pants' is used in pairs.

questions.text: ―Where are the students? Are they in <blank>?
questions.explanation: When a number is used to specify a room, we don't need an article before it.

questions.text: Excuse me, where is the <blank>?
questions.explanation: Men's room refers to the room for men.

questions.text: We need some more <blank>. Can you go and get some, please?
questions.explanation: 'Potatoes' is the plural form of potato.

questions.text: The post office is a bit far from here. It's about <blank>.
questions.explanation: Thirty minutes' walk means the walk of thirty minutes.

questions.text: She was very happy. She <blank> in the maths test.
questions.explanation: The sentence indicates past tense. 'Mistakes' is the plural form of 'mistake'.

questions.text: He went to <blank> shop to buy a shirt.
questions.explanation: Apostrophe is needed to indicate belonging. 'The tailor's' means the shop of the tailor.

questions.text: Each of us has to write a <blank> report every two weeks.
questions.explanation: When used as an adjective, 'hundred' should not be plural.

questions.text: Ask the naughty boys not to make any <blank>. I can't fall asleep.
questions.explanation: Noise refers to unwanted or unpleasant sound.

questions.text: Half <blank> telephone calls are made in English.
questions.explanation: The world means the earth.

questions.text: ―How deep is the hole? ―It is <blank>.
questions.explanation: When used as an adjective, 'metre' should be singular.

questions.text: September is <blank> month of a year.
questions.explanation: The ninth month refers to the ordinal number, so 'the ninth' is correct.

questions.text: <blank> of the people here speak French.
questions.explanation: 'Two thirds' is the correct way to express the fraction.

questions.text: There are about two <blank> students in our school.
questions.explanation: When 'thousand' is preceded by a specific number (two), it remains singular.

questions.text: Pass me <blank>, please.
questions.explanation: 'Paper' is an uncountable noun, so it needs a unit like 'pieces of'.

questions.text: Two hours <blank> enough time to spend writing that paper.
questions.explanation: When expressing a period of time as a single unit, use the singular form of the verb.

questions.text: She has a <blank> baby.
questions.explanation: When using age as an adjective before a noun, use 'hyphenated + singular noun + old'.

questions.text: The <blank> paragraphs need rewriting.
questions.explanation: 'First four' correctly modifies the plural noun 'paragraphs'.

questions.text: When he came back to China in <blank>, he was already in <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'The sixties' refers to the decade, and 'his sixties' refers to the age range.

questions.text: In a short while the seagulls ate up <blank> locusts.
questions.explanation: 'Several hundreds of' is the proper way to express multiple hundreds in this context.

questions.text: She often gets up <blank>.

choices.A: at six thirty in the morning
choices.B: at six thirty of the morning
choices.C: in the morning at six thirty
choices.D: in the morning of six thirty

questions.explanation: 'At' is used with specific times, and 'in the morning' is the correct prepositional phrase.

questions.text:
"Is that Jane and Mary's house?"
"No, <blank> is the one across the road."
questions.explanation: "Theirs" is the possessive pronoun that correctly replaces "Jane and Mary's house".

questions.text: <blank> rice do you want?
questions.explanation: "How much" is used to quantify uncountable nouns like "rice".

questions.text: She has <blank> of good friends in that school.
questions.explanation: "A lot" is followed by "of" and is used before plural nouns.

questions.text: Are <blank> boys playing games there?
questions.explanation: "All the" is the correct structure before a specific plural noun.

questions.text: School <blank> at 4:30 in the afternoon.
questions.explanation: "Is over" indicates the state of being finished, and agrees with the singular subject "school".

questions.text: Is it time <blank> lunch?
questions.explanation: "To have" is the correct infinitive form to follow "time" in this context.

questions.text: There is <blank> difference <blank> us.
questions.explanation: "No difference" is the idiomatic expression, and "between" is used to compare two things.

questions.text: She often <blank> to school <blank> 7:10. She doesn't like <blank> late for school.
questions.explanation: "Gets" agrees with "she," "at" indicates time, and "to be" is the infinitive form after "like".

questions.text: My family <blank> TV now.
questions.explanation: Although 'family' can be seen as plural, in this case it is seen as a whole, 'are watching' is used to describe an action in progress.

questions.text: You can borrow my books. But you must <blank> soon.
questions.explanation: With separable phrasal verbs, the pronoun object must go between the verb and the particle.

questions.text: She doesn't like <blank> basketball or <blank>.
questions.explanation: "Like" is followed by a gerund (playing), and parallel structure requires another gerund (swimming).

questions.text: Lucy and Lily are <blank>, but they can speak <blank> Chinese.
questions.explanation: People from America are 'American'. "A lot of" is used to express a large quantity of something.

questions.text: Sorry, we don't have <blank> cakes today. What about <blank> bread?
questions.explanation: "Any" is used in negative sentences and questions, and "some" is used in affirmative statements and offers.

questions.text: <blank>, are you from England?
questions.explanation: "Excuse me" is a polite way to start a question or conversation with a stranger.

questions.text: This question is of the <blank> of all.
questions.explanation: The superlative form 'most important' is used to compare three or more things, indicating the highest degree of importance.

questions.text: <blank> lessons are not easy.
questions.explanation: The correct order of adjectives is: opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, and purpose. Therefore, 'first few short English' is the correct order.

questions.text: Many young people consider it the <blank> music.
questions.explanation: The correct order of adjectives is: opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, and purpose. 'Best' is an opinion, 'modern' is age, and 'American' is origin.

questions.text: I don't think that your bag is <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Worth' can be directly followed by the noun it modifies without a preposition, while 'worthy' requires a preposition like 'of'. So 'worth the price' is correct.

questions.text: --What a big bag! --But mine is <blank> this one.
questions.explanation: The correct structure for comparing two things with 'twice' is 'twice as + adjective + as'.

questions.text: There are <blank> 2, 000 people on the playground.
questions.explanation: 'No less than' means 'at least', which is appropriate for indicating a minimum number of people.

questions.text: We think it <blank> that young men should master <blank> one foreign.
questions.explanation: 'Necessary' is an adjective that describes the state of being required. 'At least' means 'the minimum'.

questions.text: Tom was very <blank>, but he is now a man.
questions.explanation: 'Ill' (adjective) describes someone who is not in good health, and 'healthy' (adjective) is its opposite.

questions.text: <blank> expensive petrol becomes, <blank> we drive.
questions.explanation: The structure 'the + comparative, the + comparative' shows a proportional relationship. In this case, 'The more expensive petrol becomes, the less we drive' indicates an inverse relationship.

questions.text: Holiday flights are getting <blank> expensive, so the students want to travel to Tibet this summer holidays.
questions.explanation: 'More and more' indicates a continuous increase in the degree of something.

questions.text:
--Are you going to the basketball game?
--No, the tickets are <blank> for me.
questions.explanation: 'Far too' is used to emphasize that something exceeds a limit or is excessive.  'Expensive' is an adjective, so 'much' isn't appropriate.

questions.text: The population of China is <blank> than <blank> of the U.S.A.
questions.explanation: 'Larger' is already a comparative adjective, so 'more' is redundant. 'Much' can be used to modify a comparative adjective. 'That' is used to refer to a singular uncountable noun, 'population'.

questions.text: Two of the little girls have to sleep in one bed, but the other three in <blank> ones.
questions.explanation: 'Separate' is used to indicate distinct and individual beds, contrasting with the single bed shared by the two girls.

questions.text: 'She is <blank> fifteen years old' means 'She is fifteen years old.'
questions.explanation: 'No more than' means 'only', indicating an upper limit. Therefore, 'She is no more than fifteen years old' means she is only fifteen years old.

questions.text:
--It's six o'clock and the teacher is still at the office.
--I know. Who else would <blank> he does?
questions.explanation: The structure 'as + adjective + as' is used to make comparisons. 'Work as hard as' means working with the same level of effort as someone else.

questions.text: Jimmy Carter is one of the <blank> American Presidents.
questions.explanation: 'Living' means currently alive. 'Lively' means full of energy and enthusiasm. 'Alive' is typically used after a verb. 'Live' means to be alive or broadcast.

questions.text: I covered a distance of <blank>.
questions.explanation: When using a number and unit of measure as an adjective, the structure is usually 'number + unit + long/tall/etc.'. The unit ('mile') should be plural when the number is not one.

questions.text: No one can be <blank> for the job <blank> he is.
questions.explanation: To say that someone is the best person, we can use the structure 'more fit than'.

questions.text: I'll help you as <blank> as I can.
questions.explanation: 'As much as possible' is a common phrase that expresses the desire to help to the greatest extent possible. 'Much' modifies uncountable nouns and actions.

questions.text: She went by train <blank> Shanghai, and then took ship <blank> Japan.

choices.D: as far as, as far as

questions.explanation: 'As far as' is a prepositional phrase used to indicate the extent of something, and 'to' is a preposition indicating direction or destination.

questions.text: -What's the English for"电子邮件"?
questions.explanation: The English for "电子邮件" is E-mail.

questions.text: ―When were you born?
questions.explanation: We use 'in' for years.

questions.text: ―Do you know <blank>she came here?
questions.explanation: "How" asks about the way/method of doing something.

questions.text: ―Who taught you to play basketball?
questions.explanation: Myself is a reflexive pronoun, which means 'by oneself'.

questions.text: ―I didn't start well.
questions.explanation: Everything will become easy.

questions.text: ―What's wrong with you? You look so tired．
questions.explanation: Couldn't means wasn't able to.

questions.text: ―Thank you so much for the book you sent me．
questions.explanation: It's polite to say that you are glad that the person likes it.

questions.text: ―You don't come from England,do you?
questions.explanation: The answer follows the rule of tag questions. The speaker said, 'You don't...', so we should answer No, I don't.

questions.text: --Have you read this book?
questions.explanation: The action happened two weeks ago.

questions.text: ―Excuse me．Is there a flight to Shanghai?
questions.explanation: I have to check my computer to see if there is a flight.

questions.text: --When was the PLA founded?
questions.explanation: PLA was founded on August 1, 1927.

questions.text: ―If you want to go out of a cinema,which sign should you follow?
questions.explanation: Exit means 'go out'.

questions.text: ―There's something wrong with my radio．
questions.explanation: Never mind means 'it doesn't matter'.

questions.text: ―Tom is terribly ill.
questions.explanation: Send him to hospital as quickly as we can.

questions.text: ―What about these two coats,madam?
questions.explanation: Neither of them fits me. Could you show me another one?

questions.text: There is going to <blank> a sports meeting in our school next week.
questions.explanation: The sentence structure 'There is going to be' indicates a future event, and 'be' is the correct verb to use in this context.
questions.test_point: Verb Tenses; Sentence Structure; Future Tense

questions.text: Of all the shoes in your shop, is this pair <blank> one?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'Of all the shoes' indicates a comparison among multiple items, requiring the superlative degree 'the cheapest'.

questions.text: ― Shall we meet at eight? ―Let's make it a quarter earlier<blank>.
questions.explanation: A quarter refers to 15 minutes.

questions.text: He's going to London by air<blank>.
questions.explanation: 'By air' means 'by airplane'.

questions.text: <blank> I open the window? It's so warm here.
questions.explanation: 'Shall I' is used to make a suggestion or ask for advice.

questions.text: He doesn't know <blank> English because he has studied it for only <blank> weeks.
questions.explanation: 'Much' is used with uncountable nouns (English), and 'a few' is used with countable nouns (weeks) in an affirmative sense.

questions.text: Eating more vegetables will keep you <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Keep' is a linking verb which needs an adjective after it. Healthy is the only adjective here.

questions.text: Bruce, Look at your dirty shoes. You'd better <blank> them right now.
questions.explanation: 'Had better' is followed by the bare infinitive. So it should be 'wash'.

questions.text: Now the air in our hometown is <blank> than it was before.Something must be done.
questions.explanation: Much can modify comparatives. Worse is the comparative form of bad.

questions.text: Do you think <blank> an American film tomorrow?
questions.explanation: The structure for 'there be' in the future is 'there will be' or 'there is going to be'. Because the question starts with Do you think, so it is an object clause, the correct answer should be B.
questions.test_point: Sentence Structure; Verb Tenses; Future Tense

questions.text: ― <blank> is it from our school to Lupu Bridge? ――About half an hour's bus ride. Shall we go and visit it?
questions.explanation: Since the answer is about distance, the question should ask for distance. How far means how long is the distance.

questions.text: Could you tell me if there is a flight to the capital <blank> March, 25th?
questions.explanation: On is used to indicate the date.

questions.text: <blank> he <blank> at this school last term? ――Yes,I think so,
questions.explanation: Last term indicates the past tense. So the answer must be A.

questions.text: He has never visited the Great Hall of the People, <blank>?
questions.explanation: The question is a negative sentence because never is a negative adverb. So the question tag should be positive. The tense is present perfect. So the answer must be B.

questions.text:
――Whose English-Chinese dictionary is this? <blank>
――It's <blank>. My parents bought it for my sister and me.
questions.explanation: The dictionary was bought for 'my sister and me', so it belongs to 'us', thus the answer should be 'ours'.

questions.text:
――Excuse me. Is this <blank> watch? <blank>
――No, it's not <blank>. It's Tom's.
questions.explanation: The first blank requires a possessive adjective 'your' to modify 'watch'. The second blank requires a possessive pronoun 'mine' as it stands alone without a noun following it.

questions.text:
――Is this Lucy's schoolbag? <blank>
――No, it's not <blank>. It's <blank>.
questions.explanation: Both blanks require possessive pronouns. 'hers' refers to Lucy's schoolbag, and 'mine' indicates the schoolbag belongs to the speaker.

questions.text:
A: Which classmate is the best friend of <blank>? <blank>
B: I think Helen is.
questions.explanation: Since there is no noun after the blank, a possessive pronoun is needed. Therefore, 'yours' is the correct choice.

questions.text: This isn't <blank> purse. I left <blank> at home.
questions.explanation: The first blank requires a possessive adjective 'my' to modify 'purse'. The second blank requires a possessive pronoun 'mine' as it stands alone without a noun following it.

questions.text:
――Can we put our sports shoes here? <blank>
――Oh,yes. Put <blank> here, please.
questions.explanation: The blank requires an object pronoun. Since 'sports shoes' is plural, the correct answer is 'them'.

questions.text: Please tell <blank> about it if <blank> doesn't know.
questions.explanation: The first blank requires an object pronoun 'her' as the object of 'tell'. The second blank requires a subject pronoun 'she' as the subject of 'doesn't know'.

questions.text: Did you enter for <blank> high jump or <blank> 200-metre race?
questions.explanation: The first blank refers to a general high jump event, so 'a' is appropriate. The second blank refers to a specific 200-meter race, so 'the' is appropriate.

questions.text: ―Do you mind if I sit here?―<blank>. It"s for Mr. Brown.
questions.explanation: 'Better not' indicates that the person should not sit there because the seat is reserved.

questions.text: <blank> it's difficult to learn English well, <blank> you should never drop it.
questions.explanation: 'Though' introduces a contrast, and no conjunction is needed after 'though' in this structure.

questions.text: ―<blank> is the capital of China?―Beijing.
questions.explanation: 'Where' is used to ask about a location.

questions.text:
―Do you know if he <blank> to my birthday party?
―I think he is coming if he <blank> free.
questions.explanation: 'Is coming' expresses a future arrangement, and 'will be' is used in the 'if' clause to describe a future possibility.

questions.text: Can you guess what the word <blank> first letter is given is?
questions.explanation: 'Whose' is used to indicate possession or belonging, in this case, the word 'whose' represents the word's first letter.

questions.text: Now another hospital <blank> in our village.
questions.explanation: 'Is being built' indicates that the hospital is currently under construction (passive voice, present continuous tense).

questions.text: Could you tell me <blank>?
questions.explanation: In indirect questions, the word order should be statement order. Therefore, 'where Mike works' is correct.

questions.text: Lucy said that she had never heard <blank> music before.
questions.explanation: The correct structure is 'such + a/an + adjective + noun + of'.

questions.text: ―I did quite well in my school basketball match.―<blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Congratulations' is the appropriate response to someone's achievement.

questions.text: ―You must do your homework more carefully next time.― Yes, I <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Will' is used to express a future intention or promise.

questions.text: ―Your name again? I <blank> quite catch it?―Martin Baker.
questions.explanation: 'Didn't' is used to express that the person was unable to catch the name at the past time.

questions.text: We must study hard in order to <blank> lost time.
questions.explanation: 'Make up for' means to compensate for something lost or missed.

questions.text: Time is limited, <blank> him do it quickly.
questions.explanation: 'Have' is used to instruct someone to do something quickly.

questions.text: Tome writes <blank> than Mike and Mary. He is <blank> of the three.

choices.B: much more carefully, the most carefully
choices.C: little more carefully, the most careful
choices.D: much more carefully, the most careful

questions.explanation: The comparative form 'more carefully' is needed, and 'the most careful' is the superlative form.

questions.text: The wind is blowing <blank>. The temperature is below zero.
questions.explanation: The sentence describes a strong wind and the temperature being below zero, indicating a harsh weather condition. 'Strongly' is the most appropriate choice.

questions.text:
―Who jumped the <blank> of all in the long jump.
―Ann did.
questions.explanation: When comparing more than two items, we should use the superlative form 'farthest'.

questions.text: Which is your <blank> sport, swimming, skating or skiing?
questions.explanation: 'Favourite' is the correct spelling for the adjective.

questions.text: Little Jack was not <blank> to pull the little girl out of the water
questions.explanation: The structure is 'adjective + enough'.

questions.text: I am <blank> afraid.
questions.explanation: 'Quite' can be used before an adjective to mean 'somewhat' or 'fairly'.

questions.text: This book is <blank> interesting than that one.
questions.explanation: 'Less' is used to indicate a smaller amount or degree of something, making it suitable for expressing that one book is not as interesting as the other.

questions.text:
―<blank> does Mr. Mott go to Taipei on business?
―At least once a month.
questions.explanation: 'How often' is used to ask about the frequency of an action.

questions.text:
―How was the weather yesterday?
―It was terrible. It rained <blank>. People could go out.
questions.explanation: It rained 'hard' means the rain was heavy. People could 'hardly' go out means it was difficult for people to go out.

questions.text: Can you tell me <blank> <blank>?
questions.explanation: The correct word order is 'something + adjective'.

questions.text: India has the second <blank> population in the world.
questions.explanation: 'Largest' is the correct superlative adjective to describe the size of the population.

questions.text: He can speak English <blank> Chinese.
questions.explanation: The sentence means he can speak both English and Chinese. 'and' is used to connect two similar items.

questions.text: Physics is not so easy, <blank> I like it very much.
questions.explanation: 'but' indicates a contrast. The first part says physics is not easy, but the second part says I like it, which is contrasting.

questions.text: Will Tom wait for her at home <blank> at the library?
questions.explanation: 'or' is used to present a choice between two options: at home or at the library.

questions.text: She has a son <blank> a daughter.
questions.explanation: 'and' is used to connect two similar items, in this case, a son and a daughter.

questions.text: I have bought a new watch because my old <blank> doesn't work.

questions.text: Last Sunday everybody went to the cinema except <blank>.

questions.text:

questions.text:

questions.text: Mrs. Liu is kind and always <blank> her help to others.

questions.explanation: This is an embedded question.  Embedded questions use statement word order, not question word order. Also, since it occurred yesterday, past tense is needed. Therefore, "how much he paid for" is correct.

Wei Hua studies hard.
<blank>.

questions.text: <blank> useful dictionary for beginners of English! Where did you get it?
questions.explanation: 感叹句考查。句意：对于英语初学者来说，多么有用的字典啊！你在哪儿弄到的？useful是辅音音素开头的单词，所以用a修饰。
句意：——吉姆在哪儿？我想和他下棋。——他去电脑室了。你可能在那儿找到他。has been to 曾经去过某地，现在已经回来了。has gone to 已经走了，去某地了，现在不在这里。根据语境可知，应该用has gone to。
句意：你已经完成了大部分工作，所以你明天没必要那么早开始工作。你可以在9点来。can't不可能；mustn't禁止；needn't没必要；couldn't不可能。根据语境可知，应该用needn't。
句意：——你介意把吉他带到办公室吗？——一点也不。请把它放在我的车里。Not at all一点也不；Of course当然；Yes, I do是的，我介意；Never mind没关系。根据语境可知，应该用Not at all。
句意：没有人法语说得比他更好。所以他可以成为一个法语节目的电视主持人。as beautiful as像……一样漂亮；as badly as像……一样糟糕；worse than比……更糟糕；better than比……更好。根据语境可知，应该用better than。
句意：——刘翔参加过多少次世界比赛？——我不知道。让我们在网上查一下吧。How many times多少次；How long多久；How soon多快；How much多少。根据语境可知，应该用How many times。
句意：——我的自行车不见了。我到处都找不到它。——恐怕你不得不买一辆了。it特指；one泛指；any任何；few几乎没有。根据语境可知，应该用one。
句意：——你昨天打羽毛球了吗？——是的。但是这些天我很少打羽毛球，因为我的右脚受伤了。usually通常；always总是；never从不；seldom很少。根据语境可知，应该用seldom。
句意：火持续了半个小时才被消防员扑灭。take out取出；blow out吹灭；put out扑灭；cut out切掉。根据语境可知，应该用put out。

questions.explanation: When using a noun as an adjective to describe another noun, make the first noun plural if it refers to more than one. 'Women' is the plural of 'woman'.

questions.text: Three months <blank> a long time for me.
questions.explanation: When we treat periods of time, sums of money, or distances as a single unit, we use a singular verb. 'Three months' is considered a single period.

questions.text: There are <blank> and <blank> on the table.

choices.A: two boxes cake; four bottle of oranges
choices.B: two boxes cake; four bottle of orange
choices.C: two boxes of cakes; four bottles of orange
choices.D: two box of cakes; four bottles of oranges

questions.explanation: The correct plural form of 'box' when used with 'of' is 'boxes of', and the correct plural form of 'bottle' when used with 'of' is 'bottles of'. 'Cakes' is also correct because there are different kinds of cake.
questions.test_point: Nouns; Plural Forms; Countable & Uncountable Nouns

questions.text: I think English is as <blank> as math.
questions.explanation: The 'as...as' structure requires the base form of the adjective.

questions.text: Which subject do you like <blank>, math, Chinese or English?
questions.explanation: When choosing between three options, 'better' is the comparative degree for two options, but 'best' can be used in this specific three-item question. 'Better' here works because the question implies a comparison between each subject, rather than a definitive superlative.

questions.text: Beijing is one of <blank> cities in China.
questions.explanation: When using 'one of' with a superlative, we need 'the largest'.

questions.text: Lucy is <blank> of all.
questions.explanation: When comparing among all, we need the superlative form, and we need 'the' before the superlative.

questions.text: Of all the students in our class, Betty writes <blank>.
questions.explanation: When comparing actions among all, we need the superlative adverbial form. B is correct because 'most carefully' is used to describe the action of writing.

questions.text: Can you do the work with <blank> money and <blank> people?
questions.explanation: 'Less' is used for uncountable nouns (money), and 'fewer' is used for countable nouns (people).
questions.test_point: Determiners; Countable & Uncountable Nouns; Comparatives & Superlatives

questions.text: Chinese is the language spoken by the <blank> number of the people in the world, but it's not as <blank> as English.
questions.explanation: Since it's a comparison among all language, we need the superlative 'largest'. The word 'widely' describes the degree of being spoken.

questions.text: Kate has some apples. Jim has <blank> apples than Kate. Meimei has <blank> of all.
questions.explanation: Since it's a comparison between Jim and Kate, we need the comparative 'more'. And among all people, the correct form is 'the most'.

questions.text: Bob is <blank> of the two boys. Mary is <blank> of the three girls.
questions.explanation: The first comparison is between two boys, requiring 'the taller'. The second one is among three girls, requiring 'the shortest'.

questions.text: This one is not good, that one is <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Worse' is the comparative form of 'bad'. 'Even' emphasizes the degree.

questions.text: Let's go by car. It's <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Cheaper' is the comparative form of 'cheap', and 'much' can be used to modify comparatives.

questions.text: He drives much <blank> than he did three years ago.
questions.explanation: We need 'carefully' as the adverb. D is incorrect because 'more carefully' would be redundant with 'much'.

questions.text: Oh, dear! I <blank> the key <blank> the bike at the office.

questions.text: Yesterday <blank> 8-year-old boy fell into the river. <blank> boy was saved by <blank> policeman.
questions.explanation: The first blank requires 'an' because '8' sounds like a vowel. The second blank requires 'The' because it refers to the specific boy mentioned earlier. The third blank requires 'a' because it is a general reference to a policeman.
'None' is appropriate because it indicates that zero of the wife and children live with him, which is the correct meaning based on the context.
'Had been over' is the past perfect tense, which is used to indicate that the fashion show was completed before they arrived.
'Might' expresses a possibility, which is suitable since Millie is free and watching the game show is an option, not a necessity.
If the line of cars was endless, it seems 'hopeless' to walk across the street.
'Thanks, Millie' is the appropriate response to 'Good luck'.

choices.A: if did your uncle catch the "bird flu" virus
choices.B: who has been sent up into space in "Shenzhou-VI"
choices.C: when Zhalong Nature Reserve became one of the world's important wetlands
choices.D: that the 2008 Olympic Games will be held in Beijing

questions.explanation: Option C is the only grammatically correct indirect question. The word order is correct.
The correct structure is 'I think it is necessary for someone to do something'.
The word 'effort' means 'to try hard' which aligns the sentence meaning
The proper tense of 'looked' is past tense, 'saw' means seeing a running action, and 'running' is used to depict an ongoing action.
'Used to work' expresses a past habit or state that is no longer true. 'Was used to working' means being accustomed to the action of working, which doesn't fit.
The sentence structure 'not as...as' makes an equal-level comparison, saying climbing is not as exciting as skiing.
'Was' is used because 'traffic' is an uncountable noun, which takes a singular verb. 'Because of' is used to indicate a reason or cause.
questions.test_point: Countable & Uncountable Nouns; Cause & Effect; Grammar

―<blank> did you have the party last night?

questions.text: ―Must I finish the work today?―No, you <blank>. You <blank> finish it tomorrow.

questions.text: ―Do you mind my smoking here?―<blank>. Look at the sign. It says, "No smoking".

A: What are the boys doing?
B: They are looking for the cage that Polly <blank>.

questions.text: --Whose English-Chinese dictionary is this? """--It's <blank>. My parents bought it for my sister and me.

questions.text:
-- Have you seen <blank> umbrella here?

questions.text:
-- How old is the baby?

questions.explanation: When used as an adjective, 'month' should be singular.  When used as a noun, it should be plural.

questions.explanation: "more" is used before adjectives to make comparative form. The World Cup Soccer is held, so it is Passive Voice.

-- Jim finds <blank> easy to remember all the English words.
-- <blank> a smart child he is!
questions.explanation: The first blank needs a dummy pronoun 'it'. The second blank needs 'What' to express surprise.

questions.text:

questions.explanation: "look for" means to search for, and "look like" means to resemble.

questions.text:
-- What <blank> your father doing at eight yesterday evening, Sandy?

questions.explanation: Since the subject is your father, we should use "was". "reading" is to read a newspaper.

questions.text:
-- Where is Sally?

questions.text:
-- Your coffee smells <blank>.

questions.text:

questions.text:
-- Did you go to school party last night?

questions.text: My grandfather has sent me <blank> e-dog as my birthday present.
questions.explanation: The word 'e-dog' starts with a vowel sound, so 'an' should be used.
When comparing three or more items, we use the superlative form 'the most'.
'Who' is used to ask about the person who will repair the robot.
Prefer doing sth to doing sth. Gerunds are needed here.
'I'd like to' expresses a polite refusal with regret.
In conditional sentences, the if-clause uses the present simple tense to refer to the future, and the main clause uses 'will'.
'Vegetables' is countable, so 'more' is used. 'Meat' is uncountable, so 'less' is used.
The past continuous tense 'were planning' indicates an ongoing action at the time when I came inside.
The structure 'It is impossible for sb to do sth' is used to express that it is impossible for someone to do something.
'So' is a conjunction that indicates a result or consequence.
'Gave up' means stopped doing something.
In indirect questions, the word order should be subject + verb.
'Boring' describes the quality of the speech, and 'bored' describes how the audience felt.

questions.text:
—How do you like Beijing, Mr. Black?

questions.text: --How do you like the new movie? --Oh, it's very <blank>.

-Excuse me. Do you know <blank> Henry is going to stay in Paris?

questions.explanation: 'How to protect' is the correct infinitive phrase to use here.

questions.text: Who can <blank> the differences between the two pictures?
questions.explanation: 'Tell' is the correct verb to use when referring to discerning differences.

questions.text: My brother likes to play <blank>, and my sister likes to play <blank>.
questions.explanation: We do not use article 'the' before ball games, but we do with musical instruments.

questions.text: "<blank> have you been to China, please?" "Twice."
questions.explanation: 'How many times' is used to ask about the number of occurrences.

questions.text: Teachers should teach their students not only <blank> but also <blank>.

choices.A: to read or write; to learn
choices.B: to read and write; to learn

questions.explanation: The structure 'not only...but also' requires parallel structure. 'To read and write; to learn' maintains the parallelism.

questions.text: Some of my girl students find <blank> difficult to learn physics. Can you help them?
questions.explanation: 'It' is used as a dummy subject when the real subject is an infinitive phrase.

questions.text: <blank> thin the ice is! It is dangerous to skate on it.
questions.explanation: 'How' is used in exclamatory sentences followed by an adjective.

questions.text: <blank> failed, I'll keep on trying again and again until I make it.
questions.explanation: 'Even though I've' introduces a contrast, and the present perfect 'I've failed' is more appropriate.

questions.text: The <blank> tasted the soup to see if he <blank> put enough salt in it.
questions.explanation: 'Cook' is the person who cooks, and since the tasting happened in the past, 'had' is the correct tense.

questions.text: I think you should make a mark where you have stopped <blank> so that you can know where to go on <blank> whenever you pick up the book again.
questions.explanation: 'Stopped reading' and 'go on reading' are the correct gerund phrases in this context.

questions.text: The man shot <blank> her, but when he got ready to shoot, he himself was <blank> and fell. So she escaped the shooting luckily.
questions.explanation: 'Shot at' means aimed at, 'shot' means someone shot him.

questions.text: Their performance was <blank> and so many of the audience left before the end.
questions.explanation: If so many of the audience left before the end, the performance has to be boring.

questions.text: It is <blank> difficult work that we can't finish it in a short time.
questions.explanation: The structure "such a + adjective + noun" is used to emphasize the degree of the adjective. In this case, "such a difficult work" emphasizes how difficult the work is.

questions.text: Ladies don't like others to ask them <blank>.
questions.explanation: This is an indirect question. The correct structure for an indirect question is "question word + subject + verb". Therefore, "how old they are" is the correct option.

questions.text:
– Have you sent your parents an E-mail to tell them you arrived?
-- No, <blank> of them can use a computer.
questions.explanation: "Neither" is used to indicate that not one of the two can use a computer, which is the correct meaning in this context.

questions.text: When to buy a new house <blank> yet.
questions.explanation: The sentence requires a passive voice construction because "when to buy a new house" is the subject being acted upon. Thus, "is not decided" is the correct passive form.

questions.text: I was just leaving the classroom <blank> it rained.
questions.explanation: "When" is used to indicate that one action happened at the same time or immediately after another action. In this case, the rain started as the speaker was leaving the classroom.

questions.text: What he said sounds <blank>.
questions.explanation: The verb "sounds" requires an adjective to describe the quality of the sound. "Friendly" is an adjective, whereas the other options are adverbs.

questions.text: I won't go away <blank> I see you.
questions.explanation: "Until" is used to indicate a time limit or condition that must be met before an action occurs. In this sentence, the speaker will not leave before seeing the other person.

questions.text: <blank> put on your coat, <blank> you'll catch a cold.
questions.explanation: The sentence requires a command followed by a consequence. The correct structure is "command, or + result". Thus, the correct option is "/; or".

questions.text: Last night I went to bed early but couldn't <blank>.
questions.explanation: "Get to sleep" is the correct idiomatic expression to indicate falling asleep.

questions.text:
– Li Ming thinks Jack will win the match.
-- <blank>.
questions.explanation: "So do I" is the correct response to agree with a statement. "Do" is used because the original statement uses the verb "thinks".

questions.text: Would you please <blank> me?
questions.explanation: The sentence "Would you please not trouble me?" is the correct usage of the negative form of the verb "trouble" following "please". The correct answer should be A.

questions.text: How are you getting <blank> with your classmates?
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb "get on with" means to have a good relationship with someone. Thus, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: How wonderful the film is! I have never seen <blank> before.
questions.explanation: To express a comparison, you must use comparative adjectives. A is not a correct form. B is incorrect, because it does not reflect that the film watched is better than other films. C indicates the best film, which does not correspond to the context. Thus, the correct answer is D, a better film, which aligns with the context.

questions.text: Jim didn't know what subject the teacher would <blank>.
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is "talk about" to discuss a subject. The teacher would talk about a subject.

questions.text: Fujian is <blank> the southeast of China.
questions.explanation: "In" is used to indicate a location within a larger region or area. Therefore, "in the southeast of China" is the correct prepositional phrase.

questions.text:
-- It is very important for young people to learn <blank> useful foreign language today.
-- Really?
questions.explanation: The word "useful" starts with a consonant sound, so the indefinite article "a" should be used.

questions.text: This pair of shoes <blank> Deng Hua's. They're too big for her.
questions.explanation: Since the shoes are too big for her, they cannot belong to her, so "can't be" is the correct answer.

questions.text: The movie is so <blank> that it makes me feel <blank>
questions.explanation: The first blank should be "exciting" because the movie causes the feeling. The second blank should be "excited" to describe how the person feels.

questions.text:

questions.explanation: "On" is used with specific days or dates.

questions.text: With the development of the society, parents <blank> more and more money on their children's education.
questions.explanation: "Spend" is the correct verb to use with money and the preposition "on".

questions.text:
-- Tom's birthday card is much more beautiful than <blank>.

questions.explanation: "Hers" is a possessive pronoun, meaning "her card". It's used to avoid repeating "my card".

questions.text: There is not many differences between the two. I really don't know <blank>.
questions.explanation: Since there are two options, "which" is more appropriate than "what". Also, the subordinate clause should follow the subject-verb order.

questions.text:

questions.explanation: The question should be in passive voice, asking who were invited.

questions.text:

questions.text:
-- It's seven thirty now, Tom. You must be quick, <blank> you'll be late.

questions.explanation: "Or" is used to indicate a consequence if the first action is not taken.

questions.text:
-- Would you like to go swimming alone in the river?
--Sorry, I won't. Our teachers often tell us <blank> that.
questions.explanation: The correct form is "tell somebody not to do something".

questions.text:
-- <blank> do you see a movie?

questions.explanation: "How often" asks about the frequency of an action.

questions.text: If he <blank> harder, he will catch up with us soon.
questions.explanation: This is a type 1 conditional sentence. The "if" clause uses the present simple tense, and the main clause uses "will".

questions.text:
-- Alice fell off her bike and hurt her leg badly yesterday.

questions.explanation: "Sorry to hear that" is the appropriate response to bad news.

questions.explanation: The best response is to apologize and provide a reason for being late.

questions.explanation: 7810 should be read as "seven eight one zero".

questions.text: ―May I smoke here?―No, you <blank>. This is a no-smoking room.
questions.explanation: The sentence expresses a prohibition, so 'mustn't' is the correct choice.

questions.explanation: Get means to go and obtain something, which fits the context.

questions.text: I saw a boy <blank> a tree on my way <blank>.

questions.text: ―Do you often do sports?―Yes, I do. Sports make me <blank>.
questions.explanation: Make sb. + adj. Here 'fit' is an adjective to describe the state.

questions.text: ―Will you please bring me some water, Lucy?―<blank>.
questions.explanation: 'All right' is a polite way to agree to a request.

questions.text: ―Can you remember <blank> else about the thief?―Oh, there is a small mark under his right eye.

questions.text: The old man is looking at his granddaughter <blank>. He has not seen her for a long time.
questions.explanation: An adverb should be used here, 'happily' describes the manner in which he is looking.

questions.text: ―I don't like fish <blank> chicken. What about you?―I don't like fish, <blank> I like chicken very much.
questions.explanation: The first blank requires 'or', indicating a choice. The second blank requires 'but', indicating a contrast.

questions.text: It's <blank> hard problem for the twins that <blank> of them can work it out.
questions.explanation: 'Such a' is used before an adjective + noun. 'Neither' is used because neither of them can solve it.

questions.text: The socks <blank> that nobody bought any of them.
questions.explanation: 'Cost' is the correct verb form, and 'so much' is the correct phrase.

questions.text: He lives <blank> the 11th floor <blank> that building <blank> the city <blank> London.
questions.explanation: on the floor, of that building, in the city of London

questions.explanation: Indirect question requires normal word order.

questions.text: Many children were helped <blank> to schools by the Hope Project.
questions.explanation: helped sb. to do sth.

questions.explanation: worse means more ill, comparing two states

questions.text:
--My calculator <blank>. What can I do in the math class?

questions.text:

questions.text:

questions.text: I don't like reading <blank> watching TV. What about you? ＾I don't like reading all day, <blank> I like watching TV plays.￣

questions.text: You won't know the value of health <blank> you lose it.

questions.text: He ran <blank> fast <blank> he won the race.

questions.text: He is only ten months. He can <blank> read <blank> write.

questions.text: It was already ten o'clock <blank> we got to the museum this morning.

questions.text: It's a long time <blank> we met last.
questions.explanation: 'Since' is used to indicate the time from which something has been happening. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: That maths problem is <blank> difficult <blank> nobody can do it.

questions.text: I'll give her the message <blank> she comes back.

questions.text: <blank> the teacher came into the classroom, many students were talking to each other.

questions.text: Could you tell me <blank> in your home town in winter?

questions.text: Read the sentences slowly <blank> we can understand what you read.

questions.text: There was a boy <blank> in the river.

questions.text: I hope <blank> him as soon as possible.

questions.text: <blank> in bed is bad for your eyes.

questions.text: Guangdong Province is <blank> the south of Zhejiang Province. And the two provinces are both <blank> the southeast of China.

questions.text: I don't know <blank> he will come tomorrow. <blank> he comes, I'll tell you.

questions.text: The bookstore is <blank> 96 Fuzhou Road, just <blank> the opposite of the street.

questions.text: --How long may I <blank> the books? --Two weeks.

questions.text: How is the weather today? -- It's <blank>.

questions.explanation: shouldn't 表示不应该，我不应该告诉John这个坏消息，我认为这会让他难过。

questions.text: Could I call you by your first name? --Yes, you <blank>.
questions.explanation: may表示可以，我可以叫你的名字吗？可以。

questions.text: Let's go to the cinema, shall we? -- <blank>.
questions.explanation: Shall we? 的否定回答应该用No, we'd better not.

questions.text: <blank> the man there be our new teacher? --He <blank> be, but I'm not sure.
questions.explanation: can表示可能，may表示可能，那个人可能是我们的新老师吗？他可能是，但是我不确定。

questions.text: Sometime is knocking at the door. Who <blank> it be? --It <blank> be Tom. He is still in the school.
questions.explanation: can表示可能，can't表示不可能，有人在敲门。会是谁呢？不可能是Tom。他还在学校里。

questions.text: You won't know the value of the health <blank> you lose it.
questions.explanation: 'Until' is the correct choice to indicate the time leading up to when you realize the value of health.

questions.text: He ran <blank> fast <blank> he won the race.
questions.explanation: 'So...that' is used to express a cause-and-effect relationship, indicating the degree to which he ran fast led to winning the race.

questions.text: She said she might come <blank> Saturday <blank> Sunday.
questions.explanation: 'Either...or' is used to present a choice between two options, Saturday or Sunday.

questions.text: That maths problem is <blank> difficult <blank> nobody can do it.
questions.explanation: 'So...that' indicates the degree of difficulty which resulted in nobody being able to solve it.

questions.text: <blank> Lily <blank> Lucy like singing.
questions.explanation: 'Either...or' is used to mean one or the other.

questions.text: They teach us English <blank> we teach them Chinese, we help each other.
questions.explanation: 'As' is used to show that two actions happen at the same time.

questions.text: It was late. She took off her clothes <blank> went to bed.
questions.explanation: 'And' is used to connect two sequential actions.

questions.text: The students should know <blank> what <blank> why.
questions.explanation: 'Both...and' is used to indicate that they should know both what and why.

questions.text: The ground must be just right, <blank> too wet <blank> too dry.
questions.explanation: 'Neither...nor' is used to indicate that it should not be too wet or too dry.

questions.text: Would you like rice <blank> noodles?
questions.explanation: 'Or' is used to offer a choice between two options.

questions.text: You must eat less food and take more exercise, <blank> you'll be very fat.
questions.explanation: 'Or' indicates that if you don't eat less and exercise, you'll become fat.

questions.text: If you don't hurry up, <blank> you'll be late for the meeting.
questions.explanation: 'Or' indicates the alternative outcome if you don't hurry.

questions.text: Paul comes from Canada, <blank> he can speak very good Chinese.
questions.explanation: 'But' shows a contrast between his origin and ability to speak Chinese.

questions.text: Mother was cooking <blank> I left home.
questions.explanation: 'When' indicates the time at which the action occurred.

questions.text: We are hungry, I would like a bowl of rice, <blank> my mother would like some dumplings.
questions.explanation: 'While' is used to show a contrast or comparison between two simultaneous actions or preferences.

questions.text: Harry Potter Ⅲ is <blank> interesting story and we all like it.
questions.explanation: The word "interesting" starts with a vowel, so we should use "an" before it.

questions.text: —Are you going to watch the TV play with us? No, thanks. I <blank> it.
questions.explanation: The person has already watched it, so the action is completed. Thus, we should use the present perfect tense.

questions.text: The Smiths <blank> sending e-mails <blank> letters．because it is faster．
questions.explanation: prefer to do sth. rather than do sth. 喜欢做...而不喜欢做...，The Smiths是复数，所以用prefer。

questions.text:
―Why are you so 1ate? I have waited for more than an hour．
―I got up 1ate and missed the bus．
questions.explanation: I'm terribly sorry表示非常抱歉，符合题意。

questions.text: We <blank> them £600 <blank> the work.
questions.explanation: 'paid...for' is the correct structure. We paid someone for something.

questions.text: Many people <blank> they might lose their jobs.
questions.explanation: 'are afraid that' is followed by a clause expressing a fear.

questions.text: I think he <blank> help you.
questions.explanation: 'will be able to' expresses future ability.

questions.text: "Autumn" <blank> British English and "fall"(秋天) in American English.
questions.explanation: "Autumn" is a singular noun, thus "is used in" is correct.

questions.text: She is <blank> one of the greatest singers this century.
questions.explanation: "regarded as" is the correct phrase to express someone is considered to be something.

questions.text: <blank> going out for a picnic if we are free this weekend.
questions.explanation: "How about" is used to make a suggestion.

questions.text:
--She's been late twice this week.
--It's nothing strange. It happens <blank>.
questions.explanation: "all the time" indicates it happens frequently, which fits the context.

questions.text: I was so angry that I couldn't <blank>.
questions.explanation: The context requires an action that one might be unable to do when extremely angry. Cry doesn't fit well here, so 'speak' is correct.

questions.text: Please have a good rest at home. I won't call you <blank> there are any problems.
questions.explanation: "unless" means 'except if', indicating a condition for calling.

questions.text: There's nothing worth <blank> in this newspaper.
questions.explanation: 'worth reading' is the correct phrase.

questions.text: I really don't know <blank> the bridge will be finished.
questions.explanation: "how soon" is used to ask about the time it will take for something to be finished.

questions.text: The accident happened <blank> the afternoon of May 18th.
questions.explanation: "on" is used to specify the date.

questions.text:
-- What do you think of your new job?
-- It's not bad, but the hours are long.
-- Oh, <blank>.

choices.C: you'll soon get use to it

questions.explanation: The response indicates understanding and offers encouragement that the person will adapt to the long hours.

questions.text: We get knowledge <blank> from books <blank> through practice.
questions.explanation: "not only, but also" indicates that knowledge is gained from both books and practice.

questions.text: I want to copy the passage, but I have no pen <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'to write with' is the correct phrase because it indicates that a pen is needed to perform the action of writing.

questions.text:
― How is your father? I <blank> him for a long time.
― He is fine, but busy.
questions.explanation: The sentence describes an action that started in the past and continues to the present, so the present perfect tense should be used. Option D is the correct answer.

questions.text: I haven't checked my e-mails today, because there's <blank> wrong with my computer,
questions.explanation: Since the speaker haven't checked e-mails because the computer is wrong, 'something' is the most appropriate option.

questions.text: Bob told me that his next match was against <blank> team from another school.
questions.explanation: 'a girls'' means 'a team of girls'.

questions.text:
― Mum, could I have an MP3 like this?
―Certainly, we can buy <blank> one, but as good as this.
questions.explanation: Since there's 'as good as this' later in the sentence, which means the 'MP3' they are going to buy should be cheaper than 'this', so comparative degree should be used. Option C is the correct answer.

questions.text:
―Isn't Jim back yet? <blank>.
―No, but I think he <blank> in half an hour.
questions.explanation: The sentence indicates a future action, so the future tense should be used. Option B is the correct answer.

questions.text: Today the forests have almost gone." People must <blank> down the many trees.
questions.explanation: 'be stopped from doing' means 'prevented from doing'.

questions.text:
―Could you tell me <blank> you'll be away?
―Only one week.
questions.explanation: Since the answer is about duration, 'how long' should be used.

questions.text: Excuse me, could you please tell me which gate <blank>?

choices.C: do we have to go to
choices.D: did we have to go to

questions.explanation: This is an indirect question, so the word order should be 'subject + verb'.

questions.text: In some places there are watchtowers on the beaches to <blank> people about sharks in the water.
questions.explanation: Watchtowers are there to warn people about sharks.
